code: @Manual{,   title = {TheOpenAIR: Integrate 'OpenAI' Large Language Models into Your 'R' Workflows},   author = {Ulrich Matter and Jonathan Chassot},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {http://openair-lib.org/}, }

what: Integrate OpenAI Large Language Models into Your R Workflows
title: Integrate OpenAI Large Language Models into Your R Workflows
text: Integrate OpenAI’s GPT models R workflows.

title: Integrate OpenAI Large Language Models into Your R Workflows
text: can install development version OpenAIR GitHub :

title: Integrate OpenAI Large Language Models into Your R Workflows
text: use package, ’ll need OpenAI API key. can sign API key . API key, can start using TheOpenAIR: , can start chatting model. simplest way interacting ChatGPT chat()-function. Using essentially interacting ChatGPT via web GUI (https://chat.openai.com/chat). chat() primarily useful interactive mode. writing short scripts developing functions based TheOpenAIR, infix function %c% provides alternative syntax send messages model indicate output format required.
code: # load the package library("TheOpenAIR")  # register your api key openai_api_key("YOUR-API-KEY") # use chat() to interact with ChatGPT through the R console chat("Write a 100 words essay on why TheOpenAIR,  an R package to integrate GPT models into your R workflows is fantastic.  Write it in the style of product launches moderated by Steve Jobs.") Ladies and gentlemen, let me introduce you to TheOpenAIR, the latest and greatest addition to the R community. Thanks to TheOpenAIR, you can now integrate the cutting-edge GPT models right into your R workflows, unlocking a world of possibilities for predictive modeling and natural language processing. Whether you're an experienced data scientist or a newcomer to the field, TheOpenAIR makes it easier than ever to create powerful models that generate high-quality text. From business applications to academic research, TheOpenAIR has the power to transform the way we work with language data. So what are you waiting for? Join the excitement and embrace the future of data science with TheOpenAIR! chat("Now shorten the essay to 30 words.") TheOpenAIR - unleash the full power of GPT models in R workflows. # output to console "Remove all numeric characters from '5XC-2a09ujnap9o2q0MP'" %c%  "message_to_console" The string without numeric characters would be 'XC-aujnapqMP'. # return the message as a string resp <-  "Remove all numeric characters from '5XC-2a09ujnap9o2q0MP' In your response, only provide what remains from the string" %c% "message"   resp [1] "XC-aujnapoqMP"

title: Integrate OpenAI Large Language Models into Your R Workflows

what: TheOpenAIR: Integrate 'OpenAI' Large Language Models into Your 'R' Workflows — TheOpenAIR-package
title: TheOpenAIR: Integrate 'OpenAI' Large Language Models into Your 'R' Workflows — TheOpenAIR-package
text: Utilizing 'OpenAI' API back end (https://platform.openai.com/docs/api-reference), 'TheOpenAIR' offers 'R' wrapper functions 'ChatGPT' endpoint several high-level functions enable integration 'ChatGPT' capabilities diverse data-related tasks, data cleansing automated analytics script generation.

what: Add data to a chat log — add_to_chatlog
title: Add data to a chat log — add_to_chatlog
text: function adds data -memory chat log, global environment. data can R object, vector, list, data frame. function supports adding data chat log providing either data.frame chatlog object.

title: Add data to a chat log — add_to_chatlog
Add data to a chat log — add_to_chatlog
text: msgs chatlog object data.frame containing messages added chat log. chatlog_id id chatlog object. Required provided msgs data.frame.

title: Add data to a chat log — add_to_chatlog
text: updated chatlog object newly added messages.

title: Add data to a chat log — add_to_chatlog
text: Ulrich Matter umatter@protonmail.com

title: Add data to a chat log — add_to_chatlog
code: if (FALSE) { # Add a data frame of messages to an existing chat log chatlog_df <- data.frame( user = c("user1", "user2"), message = c("Hello!", "Hi!") ) updated_chatlog <- add_to_chatlog(chatlog_df, "existing_chatlog_id")  # Add messages from one chat log to another chatlog1 <- create_chatlog("chatlog1") chatlog2 <- create_chatlog("chatlog2") chatlog1 <- add_message(chatlog1, "user1", "Hello!") chatlog2 <- add_message(chatlog2, "user2", "Hi!") merged_chatlog <- add_to_chatlog(chatlog1, chatlog2@chatlog_id) }

what: Start or continue a chat conversation — chat
title: Start or continue a chat conversation — chat
text: function starts continues chat conversation adding user's message conversation. conversation exist, new one initiated. response can displayed console, returned character vector, returned full response object ChatGPT API.

title: Start or continue a chat conversation — chat
Start or continue a chat conversation — chat
text: message character string representing message added chat conversation. chatlog_id character string representing ID chat conversation start continue. Default ".__CURRENTCHAT__". output character string indicating output format response. Default "message_to_console". Valid options  "message_to_console", "message", "response_object". ... Additional arguments pass chat_completion() function.

title: Start or continue a chat conversation — chat
text: Depending value 'output' argument, function returns one following: * "message_to_console": message containing response text printed console (default). * "message": response text character vector. * "response_object": full response object ChatGPT API.

title: Start or continue a chat conversation — chat
text: Ulrich Matter umatter@protonmail.com

title: Start or continue a chat conversation — chat
code: if (FALSE) { # Start a new chat and print the response to the console chat("What's the weather like today?")  # Continue the chat, but return the response as a character vector response_text <- chat("What about tomorrow's weather?", output = "message") }

what: Generate Text Using the OpenAI API's Chat Endpoint — chat_completion
title: Generate Text Using the OpenAI API's Chat Endpoint — chat_completion
text: function generates natural language text conversational style using OpenAI API's chat endpoint. takes series chat messages input, either data.frame chatlog object, generates text completion based conversation history specified model parameters.

title: Generate Text Using the OpenAI API's Chat Endpoint — chat_completion
code: chat_completion(   msgs,   functions = NULL,   function_call = NULL,   model = "gpt-3.5-turbo",   temperature = NULL,   max_tokens = NULL,   n = NULL,   stop = NULL,   presence_penalty = NULL,   frequency_penalty = NULL,   best_of = NULL,   logit_bias = NULL,   stream = FALSE,   top_p = NULL,   user = NULL )

title: Generate Text Using the OpenAI API's Chat Endpoint — chat_completion
text: msgs data.frame containing chat history generate text chatlog object functions optional list functions use function call. function_call optional list specifying function call use. model character string specifying ID model use. default value "gpt-3.5-turbo". temperature optional numeric scalar specifying sampling temperature use. max_tokens optional integer scalar specifying maximum number tokens generate text. n optional integer scalar specifying number text completions generate. stop optional character string character vector specifying one stop sequences use generating text. presence_penalty optional numeric scalar specifying presence penalty use generating text. default value NULL. frequency_penalty optional numeric scalar specifying frequency penalty use generating text. default value NULL. best_of optional integer scalar specifying number completions generate return best one. default value NULL. logit_bias optional named numeric vector specifying logit bias use token generated text. stream optional logical scalar specifying whether use streaming API. default value FALSE. top_p optional numeric scalar specifying top p sampling ratio. default value NULL. user unique identifier representing end-user, can help OpenAI monitor detect abuse.

title: Generate Text Using the OpenAI API's Chat Endpoint — chat_completion
text: character vector containing generated text(s).

title: Generate Text Using the OpenAI API's Chat Endpoint — chat_completion
text: Ulrich Matter umatter@protonmail.com

title: Generate Text Using the OpenAI API's Chat Endpoint — chat_completion
code: if (FALSE) { openai_api_key("your_api_key_here") msgs_df <- data.frame(   role = c(     "system",     "user",     "assistant",     "user"   ),   content = c(     "You are a helpful assistant",     "Who won the world series in 2020?",     "The Los Angeles Dodgers won the World Series in 2020.",     "Where was it played?"   ) ) chat_completion(msgs_df) }

what: Check if a text file or character string contains an R function definition — contains_r_func
title: Check if a text file or character string contains an R function definition — contains_r_func
text: function parses text file character string returns TRUE contains valid R function definition. uses regex pattern identify possible R function definitions attempts parse matched lines R code.

title: Check if a text file or character string contains an R function definition — contains_r_func
Check if a text file or character string contains an R function definition — contains_r_func
text: input character string specifying path text file, character   string containing text checked R function definition.

title: Check if a text file or character string contains an R function definition — contains_r_func
text: logical value (TRUE FALSE) indicating whether input   contains valid R function definition.

title: Check if a text file or character string contains an R function definition — contains_r_func
code: # Create a temporary file with an R function definition temp_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".R") writeLines("example_function <- function(x) {\n  return(x * 2)\n}", temp_file)  # Check if the temporary file contains an R function definition result <- contains_r_func(temp_file) print(result) # Should print TRUE #> [1] TRUE  # Check if a character string contains an R function definition result <- contains_r_func(  "example_function <- function(x) { return(x * 2) }") print(result) # Should print TRUE #> [1] TRUE  # Remove the temporary file file.remove(temp_file) #> [1] TRUE

title: Count the number of tokens in a text string — count_tokens
code: if (FALSE) { # Example 1: File path test_file_path <- tempfile() writeLines("This is a test.", test_file_path) expect_equal(count_tokens(test_file_path), 5) file.remove(test_file_path)  # Example 2: URL url <- "https://www.gutenberg.org/files/2701/2701-0.txt" count_tokens(url)  # Example 3: Character string text <- "This is a test string." count_tokens(text) }

title: Convert a data.frame to a CSV-formatted character string — df_to_csv
code: # Create a data.frame example_data <- data.frame(   Name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Carol"),   Age = c(30, 25, 28),   Height = c(168, 175, 162),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Convert the data.frame to a CSV-formatted character string csv_string <- df_to_csv(example_data) cat(csv_string) #> "Name","Age","Height" #> "Alice",30,168 #> "Bob",25,175 #> "Carol",28,162

title: Extract blocks of a specified type from a list of blocks — extract_blocks
text: Jonathan Chassot

title: Extract blocks of a specified type from a list of blocks — extract_blocks
code: if (FALSE) { # Example 1: Extract 'code' blocks blocks <- list(   list(type = "text", content = "Hello world!"),   list(type = "code", content = "print('Hello world!')") ) extract_blocks(blocks, "code") # Output: # [[1]] # $type # [1] "code" # # $content # [1] "print('Hello world!')"  # Example 2: Extract 'text' blocks blocks <- list(   list(type = "text", content = "Hello world!"),   list(type = "code", content = "print('Hello world!')") ) extract_blocks(blocks, "text") # Output: # [[1]] # $type # [1] "text" # # $content # [1] "Hello world!" }

title: Extract R code and comments from a given input string. — extract_r_code
text: character vector containing R code comment lines extracted input string. element vector corresponds one line code comment.

title: Extract R code and comments from a given input string. — extract_r_code
code:
example_string <- "This is a text string with R code and comments.
 # A comment
 x <- 5\ ny = 10
 z <- x + y
 Another line of text." extract_r_code(example_string) #> [1] "# A comment" "x <- 5"      "ny = 10"     "z <- x + y"

Expected list object.')",   "  }",   "}")  roxygen2_docu <- extract_roxygen2(func_def) print(roxygen2_docu) #> [1] "#' Extracts object from a response list"

title: Check if a character string contains valid R code — is_r

text: code character string containing R code checked.

title: Check if a character string contains valid R code — is_r
text: logical value indicating whether input code string contains valid R code .

title: Check if a character string contains valid R code — is_r
code: # Valid R code valid_code <- "x <- 5; y <- 10; z <- x + y" is_r(valid_code) #> [1] TRUE  # Invalid R code invalid_code <- "x <- 5 + 'a'" is_r(invalid_code) #> [1] FALSE

code: if (FALSE) { # Convert a simple Java code snippet to R java_code <- "public class HelloWorld {                public static void main(String[] args) {                  System.out.println(\"Hello, world!\");                }              }" r_code <- java_to_r(java_code) cat(r_code)  # Convert Java code from a file and save the result to an R file input_file <- "path/to/java_file.java" output_file <- java_to_r(input_file) }

title: Convert nested R code to pipe syntax — nested_to_pipe

text: r file path character string containing R code converted. n_tokens_limit maximum number tokens allowed input text (default: 3000). ... Additional arguments pass chat_completion() function.

title: Convert nested R code to pipe syntax — nested_to_pipe
text: r character string, function returns converted R code character string. r file path, function writes converted code new file name "-pipe.R" suffix, returns path output file.

title: Convert nested R code to pipe syntax — nested_to_pipe
code: if (FALSE) { # Converting a character string input <- "result <- mean(sqrt(abs(rnorm(10, 0, 1))), na.rm = TRUE)" output <- nested_to_pipe(input) cat(output)  # Converting a file # Create a temporary input file input_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".R") write("result <- mean(sqrt(abs(rnorm(10, 0, 1))), na.rm = TRUE)", input_file)  # Convert the file using nested_to_pipe output_file <- nested_to_pipe(input_file)  # Check the converted file content cat(readLines(output_file)) }

what: Regenerate the last response in an ongoing chat — regenerate
title: Regenerate the last response in an ongoing chat — regenerate
text: function removes last response chatlog, generates new response based updated chatlog, updates chatlog accordingly. output can displayed message console, returned message, returned response object.

title: Regenerate the last response in an ongoing chat — regenerate
Regenerate the last response in an ongoing chat — regenerate
text: chatlog_id character string specifying ID chatlog (default: '.__CURRENTCHAT__') output character string specifying output format. Options 'message_to_console', 'message', 'response_object' (default: 'message_to_console') ... Additional arguments pass chat_completion() function.

title: Regenerate the last response in an ongoing chat — regenerate
text: output 'message_to_console', function returns NULL andprints message console. output 'message', function returns character string containing message. output 'response_object', function returns full response object.

title: Regenerate the last response in an ongoing chat — regenerate
code: if (FALSE) { # Start a new chat and save the chatlog ID chatlog_id <- chat("Hello, how are you?")  # Regenerate the last response in the chat and display it in the console regenerate(chatlog_id)  # Regenerate the last response in the chat and return it as a message message <- regenerate(chatlog_id, output = "message") print(message)  # Regenerate the last response in the chat and return it as a response object response_object <- regenerate(chatlog_id, output = "response_object") print(response_object) }
